title: Fighting Fair
description: Explore the rules of engagement that make conflict productive.

questions.text: A rule I think is important for conflict is...
choices: Stay on the topic at hand
All of these should be rules

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict rules protect relationships. No attacks prevents contempt; staying on topic prevents escalation; no past-bringing prevents kitchen-sinking. Agreed-upon rules make conflict safer and more productive.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these rules are valuable. Discuss which feel most important and create your shared rulebook.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared rules create clear expectations about how conflict should go.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What rules do you think conflict should follow? Are those rules being followed in your relationship?

questions.text: Something I try to do during conflict is...
choices: Listen to understand, not just to respond
Keep my voice calm even when upset

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict skills make disagreements productive. I-statements reduce defensiveness; understanding-listening creates safety; taking responsibility de-escalates; calm voice prevents flooding. All are learnable skills.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different skills focus on different aspects. All are valuableâ€”notice which you each prioritize and develop others.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared skill focus creates aligned effort to fight fairly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What conflict skills do you practice? Which do you want to develop?

questions.text: The thing I find hardest during conflict is...

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict challenges reveal growth edges. Calm-strugglers have regulation issues; listening-strugglers have focus issues; old-grievance bringers have accumulation; responsibility-avoiders have defensiveness. Naming challenges enables work.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different challenges need different development. Support each other's growth areas.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared challenges create mutual understanding about what's hard.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's hardest for you during conflict? What would help you grow in that area?

choices: Commitment to the relationship over winning

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about productive conflict shape behavior. Being-heard focusers prioritize validation; common-ground seekers prioritize resolution; relationship-over-winning types prioritize partnership. Aligned beliefs guide conflict approach.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these beliefs support productive conflict. Discuss which feels most important when conflicts arise.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared beliefs create aligned expectations about what productive conflict requires.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you believe makes conflict productive? Is that what you experience?

questions.text: After a fair fight, I want to feel...
choices: Like we're closer for having worked through it
Like we both got to say what we needed
Like we found a real solution

therapeutic.rationale: Desired conflict outcomes reveal values. Closeness-seekers want enhanced connection; expression-valuers want voice; solution-focusers want resolution; strength-seekers want growth. Knowing your goal helps guide conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different desired outcomes are all valid. Ideally conflict provides all of these.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared desired outcome creates aligned vision for what good conflict looks like.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you want to feel after a conflict? Is that what usually happens?
